DEBATE ON ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

(Business Motion)

 

 

         Resolved,

 

    That, notwithstanding the Standing Orders, an additional day, namely, Wednesday, 27th February 2008, be allotted for the debate on the motion for approval of the financial policy of the Government for FY 2008/2009 moved by the Minister for Finance on 15th February 2008.  -  [Mr Mah Bow Tan].

Column: 723

 

ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT

 

     Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [15th February, 2008],

 

     "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 2008 to 31st March, 2009." - [Minister for Finance].

 

     Question again proposed.

 

     Mr Ang Mong Seng (Hong Kah) (In Mandarin ):  [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  In this year’s Budget Statement, the Finance Minister announced that the Government will share the $1.8 billion surplus with the people, which includes the Growth Dividends that will cost the Government $865 million.  This is a very good surplus sharing

Column:724

package.  I support the Government in its efforts to target more help for the lower income groups, the elderly, and the most vulnerable in the society.  I am glad that the Government adopts this policy to help the lower-income group to cope with the rising cost of living in Singapore.  However, many residents are not clear about the details of the sharing of the surplus.  They asked me, "Why are there no rebates for rental, utilities and S&C charges?"  In fact, they have forgotten that last year, the Government did provide such rebates to families in these areas.  And so I said, “Last year, the Government announced a GST offset package that will be given out over four years, including rental rebates, utilities rebates and conservancy charges, and these rebates will last until 2010.” However, many residents are not aware of this, and they asked me if this was true.  They are quite doubtful.  But we know, in the past few years, the Government had given out many kinds of allowances, rebates and top-ups.  However, the calculation of these sums of money varies from time to time.  So they are confused. 

 

     As in the article "Government policies should not be too complicated" on 17th February 2008 in Lianhe Zaobao, Mr Cai Tian Cheng wrote that all these measures should be clarified and simplified so that the people can understand them.  Some people have compared the contents in the Budget sharing package to yu sheng, ie, raw fish salad dish, eaten during Chinese New Year.  Yu sheng has many tasty ingredients: colourful shredded vegetables and fruit, with freshly sliced raw fish and abalone, to entice the tastebuds.  The surplus sharing package this year is equally rich in ingredients.  The Government will give out $865 million Growth Dividends, CPF LIFE bonus, a 20% rebate on personal income tax, Medisave top-ups and more increases for top-up to Post Secondary Education Account.  These top-ups and rebates are like the ingredients of the yu sheng.  After

Column:725

tossing this salad and articulating auspicious Chinese proverbs welcoming happiness and prosperity into the New Year, the diners lift up their chopsticks to find that it is not easy to locate the raw fish and abalone slices in the salad.  Similarly, people do not realise the full benefits of the Budget sharing package.  In fact, there are many good ingredients in the Budget package, but they find it difficult to understand the contents of the Budget package and they do not understand the benefits of the package. Therefore, I hope that the Minister will simplify the details of the Budget package, by using pictorial illustrations in posters and newspaper reports, so that the people can better understand the details such as bonus amounts, distribution criteria, when and where to apply.   All these are very important contents in the Budget. 

 

     There are many people who did not know how to apply for certain benefits.  One example is the GST relief.  Until December last year, many people still have not applied.  This proves that we have to do more to publicise the benefits and details of surplus sharing with the people.  They should not be complicated so that people can understand what these packages comprise.  The Government should also put up posters explaining what these packages entail so that the people, notwithstanding their standard of education, will understand these packages and apply for them in time so as to achieve the purpose of the Government's sharing of surplus with the people.  I hope the Minister would consider my suggestion.

 

     Another issue is about CPF LIFE, the new lifelong income scheme, and this has been designed by the Government to look after the retirement benefits of the elderly people.  However, this scheme will only commence in 2013.  I would like to ask the Minister: why are we adopting this policy only in 2013?  Since everyone

Column:726

agrees that this is a good policy, can we consider the implementation of the scheme within one to two years so that our people can receive the benefits earlier?

 

       Thirdly, I would like to talk about the necessity to help Singaporeans above the age of 50 who have no CPF accounts benefit from the Government's surplus sharing packages, especially the housewives.  In the early days, the norm was for men to work and bring home the bacon while the women took up the responsibilities of the home.  Many women did not work outside their homes and have no CPF.  They shoulder the responsibilities of taking care of the home, looking after their families, and bringing up their children.  Because of their hard work in bringing up their children, we have a good generation of young people.  They have been working very hard, they do not enjoy holidays, no CPF, no bonuses.  They, too, contribute to nation-building but they have not been able to enjoy bonuses given by the Government.  They deserve a share in our surplus sharing package.  Hence, I would like to ask whether the Minister could allot a sum of money to help these women open CPF accounts and make a one-off $1,000 contribution to their CPF accounts.  The money from this account cannot be used in other ways.  It can only be used for their retirement, and their children also can top up such accounts.  With these accounts, they would be able to share in the various kinds of top-ups given by the Government to other Singaporeans and enjoy a certain level of security in their old age. 

 

     Fourthly, I would like to talk about how to help the poor start their own enterprises.  In the early days of our nation-building, our economy was weak and there were very few job opportunities.  Many Singaporeans were unemployed.  They could not find suitable

Column:727

jobs and became roadside hawkers as a means of livelihood.  This was the fastest way to solve the problem of unemployment.  Although they were poor, they were not willing to depend on the Government.  They preferred to depend on their own efforts to make some money to support their families.  This created many jobs.  However, later, the Government wanted to tidy up the city landscape and so relocated these roadside hawkers to hawker centres.   Today, our hawker centres have become a unique feature of Singapore society.  In addition to providing cheap, convenient and delicious food, such hawker centres have also become tourist attractions, attracting foreigners to have their meals there.  They contribute to our tourism sector and our economy.  Cooking has become a career for this segment of our population.  This has been a way to help the people in the low-income ground find gainful employment.  This is a good example of killing two birds with one stone.    

 

     Today, more than 40 years later, we have progressed from a developing nation to the status of a developed nation.  Although our economy is thriving, there is still a minority of people who have not been able to find jobs.  These people are forced to go to the CDCs to ask for financial assistance.  However, such short-term assistance cannot help them in their long-term livelihood.  They are given $100 to $200 a month and this money will be spent soon.

 

      Therefore, it is better to teach the people how to fish, rather than give them  fish.  And it is not easy to make a livelihood nowadays because, to start up a business, unlike in the past, it requires quite a big sum of capital.  Rental is high and they cannot set up stalls by the roadside.  I have read a book and the gist is how to make money and get rid of poverty, for instance, buying Toto or Big

Column:728

Sweep tickets.  Recently, there was a $10 million prize for Toto and many people flocked to these Toto outlets to buy Toto, but the hope of making a fortune is very slim.  The more they buy, the poorer they become.  So, why not give them some jobs or business instead? They can start with a small business.  We should help those who are enterprising, give them a helping hand, to start with a very simple business, such as setting up a stall at pasar malam, ie, night market business.  However, the pasar malam business has changed in nature.  These pasar malam stalls have been tendered out to contractors.  The poor do not stand a chance.  I suggest that the Government issue licences to such poor people who wish to become hawkers so that they can become self-reliant.  For example, in Taiwan and Hong Kong, there are tourists' streets such as Women's Street.  At night, the whole street is crowded with people.  After midnight, the street becomes very quiet.  We should adopt the same policy and allow people to work at night markets or pasar malam .  We can make use of the data from the grassroots organisationsto find out who are these poor people who are eligible for help, so that they can start up small businesses to support their families. 

 

      When I have meet-the-people session in my constituency, many residents have come to me for help to get a school canteen licence, so that they can sell food in school canteens.  However, the schools normally tender out such stalls to businessmen who in turn tender out to the highest bidders.  Therefore, such poor people are not able to get a stall licence at the school canteens.  In the early days, our school canteen operators pay only a nominal rent.  I feel that the management of school canteens should not be too commercialised.  The priority of canteen stall licences should be given to the poor people.  This is one way to help the poor people start up a small business.  So, we can consider helping them to get a loan

Column:729

from a bank so that they can start a business.  Currently, our banks do not loan funds to them.

 

      Through our CDCs, the Government has given to the poor people $100-$200 a month.  However, can the Government also consider giving them a lump sum assistance allowance, about $800 to $1,000, as a capital sum for those who are thinking about starting a small business.

 

     An economist from Bangladesh, Muhammad Yunus, has seen the exploitation of the poor by loan sharks in his country and, therefore, he started a small credit bank in Bangladesh called the Grameen Bank, offering unsecured loans to the people.  In the beginning, people mocked him for doing such a thing, and they feel that it is silly to loan money to the poor, for he might lose all his capital.  However, the bank has maintained a record of surplus revenue for nine years. Among the 6.39 million loan borrowers, 58% of them have managed to escape the poverty trap. And, so, Muhammad Yunus was awarded the Nobel Prize for Peace in 2006.  I would like to ask the Minister whether we can consider implementing similar measures in Singapore, or to consider inviting the bank to open up a branch in Singapore. 

 

     With the abolition of the estate duty, Singapore is likely to attract more wealthy people to live and invest here.  This will be a boost to our economic development.   But the question is whether our economic development will bring about a greater disparity in the income gap between the rich and poor, as this will also mean more social problems. Therefore, we should provide opportunities for the poor people, help them to find jobs, or to change our policies to help them earn a living, so that they can make due contributions to the society.  I hope the Minister would consider some of the views that I have put forward.

 

Column:730

     With this, I support the Budget.


*Cols. 863-872.

 

12.18 pm

 

     Mr Liang Eng Hwa (Holland-Bukit Timah):

 

 

     (In Mandarin ): [For vernacular speech, please refer to Appendix A *.]  This year's Budget was announced by the Finance Minister in the midst of Singapore’s rising inflation.  Like many developed countries, Singapore faces  the challenge of soaring inflation, in particular, fuel and food prices are dramatically higher.


     When I met residents in the constituency, some residents will feed back to me about the rising food prices, such as for bread, butter and vegetable oil.  They have no shortages of real life examples to share as to how they are struggling with rising food costs.


     According to the Financial Times, the global economy is facing a second wave of food inflation after the United States Agriculture Department warned of significant falls in stocks of corn, wheat and soya bean.  Officials forecast that US wheat stocks would shrink to their lowest in 60 years, and the US is the world’s biggest exporter of wheat.


     Soft wheat prices on 15th February 2008 rose to a new high of US$19.88 a bushel, three times higher compared to last year.  In the United States, the bakery sector urged the government to curb wheat exports.


     Corn and soya bean stock prices have also reached a new record high.  Rising prices for wheat, corn and soya bean will force up feedstock costs for farmers, leading to higher meat and poultry prices, including pork, beef and chicken, for consumers. 


     Through feedback from residents, I can sense that rising cost is currently the most pressing concern.  And I can

Column:731

understand their predicament, as the saying goes “Min yi shi wei tian"  (民以食为天) - people regard food as their primary concern as food is the first necessity and, as such, there is nothing more important than filling one’s stomach, and to ensure that one’s family gets three meals.


     For many years, we have enjoyed low inflation rate.  Through economic reforms and open economic policies, China, India and other developing countries have increased productivity substantially, flooding the global markets with cheap manufactured goods.  But the world is different today.  With its emergence as an economic power, China has become more affluent, and this equates with a higher consumption power on the world stage.  The country has shifted from being the largest exporter of goods to also one of the the largest importer.  Domestic demand has been growing in China, with strong demand for resources such as steel, fuel, food, etc.  This has contributed to a rapid increase in oil and energy prices.  As such, China today no longer helps in keeping world inflation at a low level.  In fact, with its strong domestic demand, it is also one of the causes of  the inflationary pressures world-wide.  Therefore, I am relieved to learn that, in this year’s Budget, besides investment in our future competitiveness, the Government has also implemented a series of practical assistance packages to help the people cope with inflation.


     Besides giving direct financial assistance to the needy, the Minister for Finance has announced a four-pronged strategy to deal with inflation and its long-term challenges, namely, exchange rate adjustments, diversifying food sources, home ownership and, in particular, strengthening our competitiveness in the long run.  To achieve sustainable growth, it is critical for us to increase our

Column:732

competency level.  By increasing competitiveness, we will have more opportunities, thus more income for the people to cope with inflation.


     On this note, I would like to make a few points.

     Firstly, strengthening of the Singapore dollar.  All this while, we have allowed for an appreciation of the Singapore dollar to reduce imported inflation.  This has been an effective strategy.  If we had not pursued a strong Singapore dollar policy, our inflation would have been higher.  However, a strong currency will reduce export competitiveness and it may also affect the tourism industry.  The Singapore dollar appreciation will also tend to lower interest rates, which means lower interest income for savers and reducing their purchasing power of their savings.  A robust economic growth will allow for the currency to appreciates, but if the Singapore dollar continues to appreciate while the economy is slowing, this will translate into slower growth in the labour market and eventually result in lower wages and employment.  Therefore, appreciation of the Singapore dollar is not an option that is always available to us.


     Secondly, to curb growth in domestic demand. Inflation in Singapore is affected by the rise in global inflation.  However, some of the inflationary pressure also originated from strong domestic demand.  For instance, if we have too many mega construction projects all going on at the same time and the construction industry cannot cope with these numbers of projects, this will inevitably push up construction costs and add inflationary pressures.  Eventually, the higher construction costs will be transferred through increased prices to the consumers.  Take, for example, our future Sports Hub.  The fund allocated for the Sports Hub has increased from $800 million to $1.2 billion.  Hopefully, this will

Column:733

not mean that sports will cost more in the future.


     Therefore, I am heartened with the Government’s effort to moderate demand in the  construction sector by deferring about $3 billion worth of developmental projects.  The construction industry is enjoying its strongest growth and, as such, the Government has taken measures to mitigate the situation.  Last year, the construction industry enjoyed a strong growth of 20.3%.  With limited capacity and foreign workers to fill the gap, any increase in demand will lead not only to unnecessary increase in prices but also an increase in construction costs.


     Thirdly, the public sector should exercise restraint in not increasing the prices of its services.  Social services such as medical services, tertiary education, JTC rental services, etc, are provided by the Government or its agencies.  Therefore, the Government should refrain from increasing the fees, and to delay price increases, if possible, so as not to add to the already rising inflationary pressure.


     I am mindful that many Government agencies are already charging a fee on a cost-minus basis and their fee revision is lagging behind the market.  Nevertheless, during this sensitive period of spiralling inflation, the Government agencies should not be ahead of the curve to increase its charges now.  This may lead to the private sector and the various industries to follow suit and increase their prices as well.  Therefore, I urge the Government to announce a one-year freeze in Government fees, including medical subsidies, as this will reduce inflationary pressure and further avoid a chain reaction from the private sector.


     Fourthly, to inculcate right values of frugality.  Many Singaporeans are not prepared that the current high level of prices is here to stay for a while.  

Column:734

According to the Financial Times report, food prices will hit a 30-year high.  Factors affecting food prices include large-scale biofuel production, severe effects of climate change on agriculture, the emergence of developing countries, etc.  These factors have affected total demand for food.  Food experts warned that this round of food prices increases may be structural and prices will not fall in the short run.


     Therefore, Singaporeans would need to adjust and make changes to their lifestyle.  Businesses are already doing so.  For example, some retailers, like NTUC Fairprice, launched their own house brand products.  These offer consumers some cheaper options and help them save money on their grocery bills.  I hope more Singaporeans will consider these house brand products.


     Currently, the Government is also looking into diversifying our food sources.  This is a very practical strategy.  Take, for instance, frozen pork.  The frozen food products can be a good alternative food source and it gives consumers another cheaper choice.  We should support and promote this policy.


     This morning, one of my office colleagues even suggested that we should consider reducing the number of dishes served at wedding banquets and dinners from usual 10 dishes to eight dishes.  Not only is it good for health, it also helps to cut down on food waste.  He said, with some humour that, “this may even take some pressure off the  hongbao inflation for wedding dinners”.  This is for reference only, and I am not advocating that we pass a law to limit the number of dishes served during wedding banquets. 


     In the next two years, the economic and inflationary outlook is uncertain and not optimistic.  Therefore, I support the Government’s policy of being prudent in its Budget, and share part of the budget

Column:735

surplus by way of giving  hongbao to the needy.  This is so because high food prices are not our only concern.  High fuel prices have also created uncertainty in the market.  The US subprime crisis is likely to drag the US economy into a severe slowdown.  This will have a direct impact on Singapore’s economy.


     A key factor behind this year’s surplus was the strong growth in the property market, where approximately $3.8 billion was collected from stamp duties on property purchases last year.  This is unlikely to be repeated again.  Budget surpluses are our precious strategic resource and we should not have a “must spent all” mentality.  Rather, it is more important that we spend it the right way and distribute assistance to those Singaporeans who need help.  The remaining surplus can still be used for rainy days in the next few years. 


     Given the uncertain prospects of the economy, we should be cautious and keep our powder dry.  This is in fact what a responsible Government should do.  The Budget stance adopted this year also signals that we need to be prudent and thrifty.


     Earlier, I have mentioned that the Government adopts a strong Singapore dollar policy to curb imported inflation.  However, the appreciation of the Singapore dollar cannot be taken for granted.  Investor confidence is one key factor to determine whether the Singapore dollar will appreciate in the foreign currency market, in particular, the financial credentials of the Government.  Therefore, I believe that prudent fiscal management will strengthen our credentials and all Singaporeans will eventually benefit from it.


     In conclusion, this year’s Budget is compassionate, prudent and farsighted,

Column:736

and it has achieved a good balance in these three areas.  Although this year’s Budget is not a pill that will cure all problems, it is indeed a pill that puts our mind at ease.


     With this, Sir, I support this year’s Budget.

12.30 pm

 

     Dr Lily Neo (Jalan Besar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I stand in support of the motion raised by the Minister for Finance.

 

     This year's Budget was clearly formulated with the most economically vulnerable group of Singaporeans in mind - the group worst hit by inflation and the rising cost of living.  I am most happy with the public assistance allowance increase.  I would like to thank and commend both the Minister for Finance and the Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports for the increase.  I am sure the 286 public assistance recipients in my constituency and throughout Singapore would appreciate the increase in their monthly public assistance allowances.

 

     I was particularly encouraged by the Finance Minister's assurance during his Budget Speech to "continue to refine the safety nets to help the most vulnerable in the community".  I endorse this initiative wholeheartedly.  Finetuning the present social support system is necessary to address the concerns of this group of Singaporeans.  I shall address this later in my speech.

 

     Today, I shall speak on: (1) the challenges faced by the lower-income group in Singapore; (2) the potential ramifications to our social fabric; and (3) propose initiatives which I hope would complement and augment current and future plans for a stronger and more refined social safety net.

 

Column:737

    Two key challenges currently facing lower-income Singaporeans are (a) real wage stagnation; and (b) job volatility.

 

     (a) Wage stagnation.  In an increasingly skills-biased economy, our low-wage workers and their families have had to run faster just to stand still.  In today's world of outsourcing and cheap international labour, it is still possible to be gainfully employed but still not earning adequately to feed one's family.

 

     Some of the deleterious aspects of globalisation have led to real wage stagnation at the lower-income levels for the first time in recent years.  The bottom 30% of working families have now experienced stagnating real household income for eight to 10 years.  Our poorest, numbering some 90,000 to 100,000 households, still earn around $160 per month per capita, the equivalent of around $640 per month for a family of four.  This compares to a measure of the average basic expenditure of around $1,040 estimated by the Department of Statistics to indicate the need for social assistance.  The poorest and least skilled have been the hardest hit.  Median monthly starting pay for cleaners and labourers has fallen by nearly 33%, from $860 to $600 between 1996 and 2006.

 

     Not all are enjoying in our recent successes.  These figures indicate that our poorest and least skilled have not only not benefited from Singapore's recent successes, they have, in fact, been hit the hardest as a consequence.

 

     (b) Job volatility.  Low-wage workers and their families are also more vulnerable to job volatility.  The increasingly competitive labour market, changes in work design, and influx of foreign workers have all contributed to increased job volatility.  Low-wage workers are typically less adept in navigating this particular challenge, whether it is to switch

Column:738

employment in the same industry, or in another industry altogether.

 

     I see two clear ramifications posed by these challenges:

 

     First, there is a limit to poverty alleviation by working longer and harder, or driving down the unemployment rate.  We cannot expect lower income Singaporeans to keep on running faster and faster but yet find themselves not progressing.  They will eventually tire out and become disillusioned, which leads me to the second ramification - the effect on our social compact.

 

    Second, there are concerns that, in the long run, the rising levels of inequality may engender the politics of envy and affect Singapore's social compact.  It is vital to maintain a strong and cohesive Singapore to meet the challenges of the future and to ride in the global growth.

 

     What then can be done?  How should we, as Finance Minister had said, "refine our safety nets to help vulnerable Singaporeans cope?" 

 

     The positives are that there have been a more diverse and greater number of schemes, which have helped up to 64,000 individuals and families last year compared to 15,000 in 2002.  These schemes have helped parents with childcare and kindergarten fees, and provided short-term aid for the unemployed until they find employment.

 

     However, short-term handouts by themselves are not sustainable and do not do enough to help these individuals and families become self-reliant.  Current net Workfare payments of around $80 to $100 per month are also barely able to bridge the gap between bare subsistence and the small surplus needed to invest in human capital at the household level.  Yet, they remain the fastest way of upward mobility without compromising work ethic and with relatively low cost.

 

Column:739

     We would have to explore the need for a stronger, direct social safety net which would enable us to take advantage of globalisation more quickly and boldly.  The continued evolution of our Workfare Income Supplement Scheme (WIS) is a step in the right direction.  This should be coupled with initiatives aimed at maximising our human capital investment.  A key strategy to circumvent the effects of wage stagnation and job volatility is to focus on upward mobility.  In other words, we need to help this vulnerable group of Singaporeans, who are running harder just to remain where they are, to move forward.  A key to upward mobility is, what I mentioned earlier, human capital investment.

 

     What can be done to ensure that lower income Singaporeans and their children are getting somewhere with all that hard running?  We need to invest in them and their children so that they can use that extra "energy" to better themselves and become more upwardly mobile.

 

     An integrated case management approach focused on human capital investment will help these individuals and families escape poverty and become more upwardly mobile.  I concur with the Finance Minister who said in his Budget Speech that "our fundamental approach to helping Singaporeans in need is to help them get a good income for themselves.  The best way to do so has been and remains to help needy Singaporeans get a job, and to encourage them to stay at it, upgrade themselves, and support their family members."  This is the essence of the human capital development approach.

 

     In this regard, I would like to propose a three-pronged approach towards the development of human capital for this group of Singaporeans.  The three aspects are: (1) direct assistance in the form of a

Column:740

package; (2) improvement of means of delivery; and (3) constant updates to training programmes.

 

       I wish to propose a new initiative in the form of a comprehensive assistance package for low-income families focused on human capital investment.  The package would include employment upgrading opportunities for parents, new employment opportunities for unemployed spouses, and continued assistance in the form of counselling, childcare, kindergarten and tuition fees for their school-going children.  Such a package would help parents with child caring responsibilities, so that the parents themselves would have more time to upgrade themselves.

 

     I am encouraged by the Finance Minister's promise to "enhance our financial assistance schemes (CFAS and KiFas) to help more families with their children's fees in kindergartens and childcare centres."  With these enhancements, any comprehensive assistance package could better help young low-income families and particularly their children, who will be given a chance to compete on equal terms.  Children from such families face a greater challenge participating in the education process.  Longitudinal studies show that when children begin education at a young age, they do not only do better in school but also become more productive as adults.  Such a package would give these families, and particularly their children, a much needed boost, enabling them to cope better in school and prevent them from dropping out.

 

     Improvement in delivering assistance to those in need is core to ensuring the development of human capital in this group of Singaporeans.  Without the proper delivery of assistance, they would not have the starting base from which to even begin.  I thus strongly suggest fine-tuning our present social services by revamping the delivery aspects, even if it

Column:741

means incurring expenses in manpower to do so.  This will ensure that the diversity of our many schemes, which have been criticised as mostly incomprehensible, reach our targeted group and reap the desired outcomes.  Such an effort would go a long way to ensure that such families will not fall through the cracks.  This would, in turn, contribute to our goal of pursuing a sustainable approach in helping lower income Singaporeans become more upwardly mobile.

 

     There need to be constant updates to existing training programmes.  Human development in training, retraining and re-employment have thus far been at the core of Government's  policy to promote upward mobility.  However, the outcome of this policy needs to be evaluated in the context of global downward pressures on market wages, particularly for the lower income.  One example is whether

 

 

existing retraining programmes can be expanded to assist workers to transit from sunset sectors to the new relevant ones.

 

     Mr Speaker, Sir, while I applaud the many positives in this year's Budget, there is still always room for improvement as we continue to seek ways to enhance our social safety nets for the well-being of all Singaporeans.  In order to "move as One Singapore",  as the Prime Minister has said, and to build a resilient community - the topic of  the Finance Minister's Budget speech this year, we must continually seek to evolve in our thinking and policies.  I have today spoken about the challenges faced by lower income Singaporeans, the possible social ramifications and have, to that end, proposed a three-pronged approach centred upon the concept of human capital investments. I hope that the Finance Minister would consider my views in earnest, in his deliberations.

Column:817

Column:819
